Award.AwardTitle: SBE-RCUK: The Development of Lexical Flexibility

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most striking features of human communication is our ability to use words in flexible and creative ways: We often use the same word to mean multiple different things. For instance, we hammer using a hammer, and drink from glasses that are made of glass. These flexible uses of words provide expressive power, but seem likely to be difficult for children to learn. Hearing the same word used in multiple ways may lead to confusion and slow down the learning process. Surprisingly, recent research suggests that flexible uses of words do not impede children from learning words, but actually appear to facilitate the process. The goal of the current project is to understand how children master flexible language so easily by studying children in structured study environments and by observing how parents and children use these words in their everyday lives.

This project will involve both tightly controlled experimental approaches and annotation and analysis of transcripts of parent-child speech. First, the project will explore how children are exposed to flexibility in their conversations with parents, and how this might vary across different languages. Second, the project will assess how children between 2- and 4-years old manage to learn the different meanings of flexible words, while at the same time keeping these meanings distinct in their heads. Investigators Srinivasan and Rabagliati will also conduct experiments to explore how children learn to use flexible words in creative ways that they could not have heard before. The final series of studies will examine what the consequences of flexibility are for children's cognitive development more generally. In particular, studies will explore whether the ways that flexible words are used in a language can teach children about the world more generally. This project is being funded jointly through a partnership between the National Science Foundation and the Research Councils of the United Kingdom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preschoolers need help tying their shoes, but they are incredibly talented learners when it comes to language. For example, most preschoolers already know thousands of words. This is a particularly impressive feat because it is not easy to learn a new word. Words are typically spoken in complex scenes, such that a new word could have many possible interpretations. This problem appears to be even more difficult when we factor in that most words are actually polysemous: they can be used with a family of distinct but related meanings. For example, the English word chicken can refer to an animal, a kind of meat, a cowardly person, or a game.

The research supported by this grant was guided by a key overarching question: Is it difficult for children to learn a new word when it carries multiple meanings? According to most theories in language development, the answer should be “yes”. For example, one prominent theory holds that, to simplify the difficulties of learning a new word, children may initially assume that each word only has a single meaning. Polysemous words, of course, violate this assumption, because they carry multiple meanings. Thus, according to previous theories, children may struggle to learn multiple meanings for words, or may learn them but think about them in very different ways from adults (for example, thinking about “chicken” as referring to a single category that includes the animals, the meat, etc.).

Through experiments with young children (mostly between ages 2 and 5), we have found not only that children do not struggle with learning polysemous words, but instead that polysemy may help children build a vocabulary. For example, our studies show that children learn multiple meanings of words from early in life, and think about them them similarly to adults (such that they understand that “chicken” refer to different kinds of things when it is used with its animal vs. its meat meaning). Moreover, our studies show that children use their knowledge of one meaning of a word to learn other, new meanings for that word. For example, in one study, we show that if children have learned that a new word refers to a kind of material (“some dax”), and then learn that the same word can refer to an object made from that material (“a dax”), children assume that the object word will refer only to objects made from that material, similar to how we use “glass” to label drinking vessels that are made of glass. In another study, we show that although children struggle to learn a new word for pitch (e.g., that “daxy” refers to a high pitch), they are much better at doing so when they have first learned that the word refers to space (e.g., that “daxy” refers to a high location in space). Finally, we find that children can use their knowledge of one meaning of a word to spontaneously guess that the word will have an additional meaning. Specifically, we find that if children learn that a word refers to an action involving a tool they expect that the word can also refer to the tool itself (just as one “hammers with a hammer”). 

In other projects supported by this award, we have asked whether polysemy may be widespread, in part, because of how it supports communication and word learning. These projects have employed computational analyses of large-scale language records. For example, one project found that, over the past millennium, speakers have been more likely to talk about new concepts by recycling existing words in their vocabulary than by inventing entirely new words. Moreover, when expressing a new meaning, speakers tend to choose an existing word with a highly related meaning (e.g., extending “face” from referring to a body part to referring to the “face” of a cube), perhaps because this maximizes mutual understanding and is beneficial for children’s word learning. Together, these findings suggest that polysemy may support communication and help make language maximally learnable.

This project has also created  broader impacts by 1) providing opportunities for training and professional development to students, and 2) through engagement with the public. Many graduate and undergraduate students at UC Berkeley have gained experience conducting research through this award, and have also received opportunities for professional development through participation at academic conferences. Topics in linguistic and cognitive development are some of the most fascinating topics in psychology, especially for parents. While conducting the projects described above, my lab members have and I regularly engaged families in their laboratory at UC Berkeley, as well as at children’s museums in the San Francisco Bay Area. Additionally, we have sent newsletters to the families of all study participants, describing study findings and their broader implications. Finally, to reach more general audiences, we have also delivered several public lectures.
